cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.)
N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.-P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 36, New Broad-street. E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS CO., LIMITED. (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, EC.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 12, 1905..

div.head: THE SUPPRESSION OF LOTTERIES.
div.p: At last the Government have put a stop to the sale of lottery tickets in our public streets, and in future this nuisance will cease. This is a matter for congratulation from every point of view, though we fear it will press somewhat hardly, for a time, upon those who have gained a scanty living by the sale of the tickets. Our only regret is that all lotteries without exception cannot be dealt with in the same summary fashion. Perhaps before long all lotteries will share the same fate, for the present exceptions are illogical. However, the Government is to be congratulated on having done something, though apart from the injurious effects of gambling upon the moral nature of the individual-a matter which hardly admits of argument-we see no reason why any one class of lottery should be exempted from the general rule. The object for which the tickets are sold has nothing at all to do with the principle involved, and it looks to us as if the practice so prevalent everywhere, of raffling for articles at bazaars held for religious and other objects, and which is openly countenanced by the clergy of all denominations, may have had something to do with this exemption of lotteries for charitable objects from the law that has just come into force. We hear from a correspondent in Cairo that some working girls, earning only P.T. 3 to 5 per day have been known to spend as much as P.T. 2 of the money so urgently wanted at home in the purchase of lottery tickets. Perhaps the new law will render this impossible for the future, but it is greatly to be regretted that lotteries of all kinds have not been suppressed, now that the matter has once been taken in hand.

There is a case in which British influence, if it is to be exerted at all for the moral improvement of the Egyptian people, should have been able to make itself felt to the fullest extent possible. It is notorious that in England. it is found impossible to check the distribution of the millions of prospectuses of foreign lotteries that are circulated throughout the country, and there need be no fear that gambling propensities will not find far too many opportunities for their indulgence, let the law be ever so strict and the endeavour to make people moral ever so earnest. But we claim that as far as law can be made effectual in closing the door to facilities for gambling of all kinds and reducing these to a minimum, so far it should be unsparingly applied, and we consider that in the present instance a great opportunity has been missed for a determined stand to be made against the practice of doing things by halves, and stopping short at a halfway house in carrying through a much-needed reform. Surely on such a question as this our British advisers could have led the Egyptian Government to see the advisability of dealing with it in a firm and effective way, and by a drastic measure have dealt a forcible blow to a practice so objectionable from both the individual and the collective standpoints, as gambling by means of lotteries.
THE MIXED COURTS AND THE S.P.C.A.

One of the minor charms of the Capitulations is that while the native can be punished with all the rigour of the law for cruelty to animals, the European almost invariably gets off scotfree, however brutal he may have been. The judgments given by the Mixed Courts at Cairo prove this, and the most cursory review of such cases shows that the upshot was a general judgment of acquittal. The grounds on which the Court based its leniency were that the police had not proved that the wounds were recent, and that in some instances the injuries may have been mere scratches or simply due to chafing from the harness. In each case the certificate of the veterinary surgeon stated that the animals were found to have wounds, and that the alleged sores were not due to mere chafing, but required from fifteen to twenty days' treatment. It is obvious that these judgments were nothing more nor less than cases of miscarriage of justice and misplaced leniency. The result of such a state of things is deplorable, for the police are naturally discouraged in their efforts to bring these inhuman offenders to justice, who, merely because they are Europeans, are enabled to escape. The police and the S.P.C.A. are doing excellent work at Cairo, and their efforts ought to receive the hearty support of the tribunals. Not only are the judges lenient, but the law is at fault. For example, no power exists whereby animals belonging to Europeans can be. sent to hospitals, while in the case of natives there is such a power. Surely both should be placed on the same footing. But it is useless to clamour for any extension of the law in this respect, if the Mixed Courts persist in regarding cruelty to animals as an absolutely venial sin on the part of Europeans resident in Egypt. The judgments which we have stigmatised above are in our opinion entirely unwarrantable, and afford deplorable examples of purposely perverted leniency,

JAPAN is meeting the Russian plan for the reorganization of Manchuria by extensive preparations, to the extent of doubling or even trebling the present units. It is estimated that by the autumn the Japanese organisation will exceeed 1,000,000 men,the actual fieldss force being, roughly 700,000. The Japanese are confident of their ability to take and hold Harbin, and, simultaneously, to operate against the Russians eastwards (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. ANCHORED NEAR ANAMBAS.

div.p: The Russian fleet has anchored ten miles to the north west of Anambas. (Havas.)
A fight between the Sultan and the Pre- tender's troops has taken place at Usda. The former had been repulsed when a French frontier force intervened, and defeated the Pretender. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE FRENCH PLOT. CAPTAIN VOLPERT ARRESTED.

div.p: Captain Volpert has been arrested for parti- cipation in the plot. (Havas.)

div.head: THE "ENTENTE CORDIALE". THE BRITISH FLEET AT BREST.

div.p: Extraordinary preparations are being made for the reception of the British fleet. The Municipal Council has voted an unlimited credit for the entertainments, and the popula- tion is organising independent fetes. (Reuter.)
House of Commons. — The Government majority fell to 12 on a motion relating to education in Ireland. (Reuter.)

H.M.S. "Juno," with troops on board, re- turned here and landed 12 prisoners. A huge crowd followed the prisoners to the police station, and cheered them. The insurgents were so menacing that the Italian detachment Was obliged to load their rifles. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday at Mariout. Today, his Highness is at Edfina. It is expected that the Khedive will attend the Zizinia Theatre this evening. Miralai Watson Bey, A.A.G.of the Egyptian Army, is to be appointed first A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: will be distributed at the. G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 6.30 p.m. to-day.
The San Stefano Casino will be opened for the summer season on Saturday next, 15th inst.

div.head: Congdon c. Houghton
div.p: The hearing of the civil action brought by Mr. Congdon, of Cairo, against Mr. W. Houghton will be heard by the Supreme Consular Court, most probably at the end of May.

div.head: Army of Occupation
div.p: Lieut-Col. A. M. Mantell, R. E., C. R E., Alexandria, has left Alexandria for Cairo in order to take over the duties of C. R. K. in Egypt during the absence on leave of Colonel L. B. Friend, R. E.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 23 vessels passed through the Canal on the 8th and 9th inst. 17 of these were British, 1 French, 3 German, 1 Spanish, 1 Norwegian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 574,752.96, making the total from the 1st inst frs. 2,406,045.53.

div.head: Rabies
div.p: The day before yesterday, an Ar- menian lady, Mme Arian, was bitten by a dog believed to be mad, in the Abdeen quarter of Cairo. Yesterday, a cat, also believed to be suffering from rabies, attacked and bit five Arabs in the Waili district, Abbassieh.

div.head: Al Azhar
div.p: The Sheikhs Bakri Sadafi and Mahmord El Geziri have been appointed members of the council of administration of the Al Azhar University in place of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou and Sheikh Abd al-Kerim Suleiman, who have resigned.

div.head: Salt and Soda Co
div.p: The sales of salt during March realised L.E. 23,072.936 as against L.E. 23,376.268 for the corresponding month in 1904 ; the total amount received from sales since January 1 being L.E. 66,787.038, while for the same period last year it was L.E. 71,934.585.

The Union Artistique Francaise willgive a dramatic performance at the Eden Theatre, Alexandria, on Saturday next, the pieces to be represented being, A la Chambree, Le coeur a ses raisons, and Uu client serieux. Misses H. Felix and Sant'Andrea will kindly assist in the musical part of the programme.

div.head: Adjudications
div.p: The contract for the con- struction of a school at Benha has been given to M. C. Zouro; for the construction of an inspection building at Kilometre 62, on the Nubarieh Canal, to M. S. Laonelli, and for certain repairs between the twenty-second and forty-fifth kilomotres, on the Mahmoudiah Canal, to M. S. Perullo.

div.head: Cleopatra Cigarette Co
div.p: We beg to draw our readers attention to the advertisement on page 1 of to-day's issue, of the Cleopatra Ciga- rette Company, which was founded a few months ago by George Nungovich Bey and Mr. Constantino Meimarachi, and has already obtained one of the highest positions in public estimation as a producer of excellent cigarettes.

div.head: Recovery of Stolen Property
div.p: A short time ago Mrs. Hazzan, a Syrian lady living in Mohamed Aly-square, had jewellery to the value of £200 stolen by a servant. Teo man was caugbt, but no trace of the booty could be found until two days ago, when it was very cleverly discovered by some Alexandria de- tectives.

div.head: Prince Colibri
div.p: This wonderful little man will hold his first reception in Alexandria this afternoon, commencing at 5 p.m., in the Alhambra Theatre. A committee of medical men in Cairo declared him to be a "most wondrous mite of humanity," and those of our readers who wish to gaze on the eighth wonder of the world should not miss such an unique opportunity.

div.head: Shooting Affray
div.p: Yesterday evening, at the 8.30 o'clock, two Italians began discharging revolvers at one another in Sisters-street, Alexandria, owing to jealousy about a woman. None of the shots took effect. The two men were cleverly captured by a policeman. This man happened to be in plain clothes at the time, and was travelling in a tramcar. When he heard the report of firearms he jumped off the tram and arrested both of them.

div.head: A Baby on the Bourse
div.p: An extraordinary "scene" was enacted this morning at the Alexandria Bourse. While the exchange was crowded a pretty young woman, carrying a baby in her arms, rushed in with the avowed object of consigning her offspring to its father, a well- known remisier, who had it appears, married and deserted her. The man in question, however, was not on the Bourse at the time, and after publicly denouncing her faithless spouse in unmeasured terms, the excited woman was politely escorted to the door.

div.head: Bandmann Dallas Opera Company
div.p: The "Daily Malta Chronicle" of the 28th inst. gives an account of the opening performance of the Bandmann Dallas opera company at the Manoel Theatre there. "A Country Girl" was produced and was witnessed by a full and appreciative house. Old favorites (says the "Chronicle") were greeted with rounds of applause, whilst the new members of the company received no less warm a reception, as they gave unmistakable proofs of artistic capabilities.

div.head: The White Slave Traffic.
div.p: —We Are glad to find on enquiry as to the progress made in this matter, that the report that the Govern- ment has contributed L E. 100 to the recently formed committee for the suppression of this vile traffic, is quite correct. We have every reason to hope that now that this matter has been taken in hand, and influential support of the movement is ensured, that Egypt will soon come into line with other countries in doing her best to prevent her ports being utilised for such purposes.

div.head: Alexandria Archaeological Society.
div.p: — With the object of giving the members of the Archaeological Society an opportunity of visiting the mosaics, discovered by Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun and offered by his Highness to the society, an excursion to Aboukir has been arranged for Monday next Prof. Breccia, Conservator of the Museum, has agreed to give a short lecture concerning the find on the spot. Those taking part in the excursion will leave Alexandria station at 4 p.m. and Sidi Gaber at 4.10 p.m., arriving at Kharabah at 4.40 p.m The return journey will be commenced at 7.22 p.m., arriving at Alexandria at 8 p.m.

CAIRO GRAND HAMMAM. Near Shepherds's & Continental Hotels. Turkish Baths, Plain Baths XRAYS. Electric Light Baths Massage & Electro-Hydropathic Baths. Medical Directors, Dr. Professer Fernario & Dr. M. Reef

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT. COLOSSAL SUCCESS.
div.p: The list of the above company closed at noon yesterday, with a result that tho Anglo- Egyptian Bank in Cairo have received applica- tions for the enormous amount of 2,990.226 shares. In Alexandria the applications amount- ed to over 6,750,000 shares; altogether a total of nearly 10,000,000.

div.head: THE POLYTECHNIC SCHOOL.
div.p: The strike at the Polytechnic School, Cairo, continues. The pupils are said to have forwarded a petition to the Ministry of Public Instruc- tion protesting against the tone of the letters addressed by the head master to their respect- ive parents. We should have thought that the parents were the best judges, but 'HysT; rfilv worfpuy paV ojulvan? «u%6|u#' rival seems to be the view generally taken, and not in this case only, by young Egypt. The peti- tioners add that if the tone of the letter is not modified they will not return to the college at all.

The situation is more absurd than ever ; we have the authorities saying in effect, "As a punishment you shall not come back for a week, but if you don't come back then w expel you," to which the pupils retort, "We promised to strike and have got a week's holi day in consequence. If you don't ask us to come back very politely we shall not come back at all.

We are glad to hear this morning that the recalcitrant pupils of the college have decided to return on Saturday, while continuing their protest against the tone of the letter forwarded to their parents by the head master. Great satisfaction will be felt at the close of an un- fortunate series of incidents.

div.head: THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: The Duke of the Abruzzi paid a visit yester- day morning to the Salisian College. At midday his Royal Highness gave a luncheon at the Mohamed Aly Club in honor of Sig. Monzani, acting Consul-General for Italy.
The Duke has given £20 to the benefit of the Alexandria foundlings. The "Liguria" leaves for Spezzia at 6 a.m. tomorrow.

The French cruiser "Encernet,"which arrived at Suez last Monday from Djibouti, will remain at this port for three weeks in order to be overhauled, and to change her crew. The "Encernet" will subsequently return to Dji- bouti.

The British cruiser "Diadem" anchored yesterday evening in the Suez roads at 8 o'clock. She will sail in a few days, after finishing coaling, bound to China, and on her way she will call at Aden and Trincomalee. This morning 1,420 Egyptians pilgrims arrived at Suez from Tor by the Khedivial Mail Line steamers: 700 by the S S. "Rah- manieh," 520 by the S.S. "Missir," and 200 by the S.S. "Callioubieh." All of them will leave Suez to-morrow by special trains for their res- pective villages.

div.head: A GRAND NATIVE WEDDING.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon and evening, receptions were held at Idris Bey Ragheb's fine house near Abdeen Palace, on the occasion of the marriage of his daughter, Fitnat Hanem, to Mohamed Bey Suleiman, son of Mahmoud Pasha Suleiman. The road leading to the house, the court, garden, and reception hall were beautifully and tastefully decorated with flowers, lanterns, and fairy lamps. Whoever was responsible for the floral decoration, deserves the utmost credit for his taste. The first reception was held at 5 p.m., the second at 9 p.m. An enormous member of guests were present, at one time reaching the imposing total of 15,000. The buffet, which was largely patronised, was under the care of Mr. Wild, the popular manager of the Savoy Hotel, and we need not say that it did him credit. Music was supplied by the Egyptian Army Infantry Band.

Among those present were Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, Boutros Pasha Ghali, Fouad Pasha, Fakhry Pasha, Dr. RuckerJenish, Aziz Pasha Izzet, Thurneyssen Pasha, Adly Pasha Yeghen, Riaz Pasha, Hilmy Pasha, Comanos Pasha, Mr. Machell, Crookshank Pasha, Dr. Pietri Bey, Piot Bey, Mr. F. Suaree, Scander Pasha Fehmy, Hassan Pasha Assem, Ibrahim Pasha Mahmoud, Prince Radziwill, Fabricius Pasha, M. Rolo, M. Sciortino, M. Anders and many other well-known members of native and European society, whose names we have not space to quote.

A reception will be given to ladies this evening at Idris Pasha Ragheb's house, and to-morrow there will be a reception at the house of the fortunate bridegroom. Our most hearty congratulations are duo to the young married pair and to their distinguished parents.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Menis" arrived at Malta on Monday morning, homeward bound.
The S.S. "Seti" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN CABLE RATES. IMPORTANT REDUCTION.
div.p: The recent negotiations between the Egyp- tian Government and the Eastern Telegraph Company have led to a decision to reduce, in principle, the cable rates to England from 1s. 5d. to 1s. per word. This decision is not officially announced, and the date of the coming into force of the new rate is not yet known. The last reduction was on July 1, 1904, when tho rate was reduced from 1s. 7d. to 1s. 5d.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Maximoff, Russia Consul General and Diplomatic Agent, paid a visit to H.E.the Governor this morning, previous to his approaching departure for Cettinge.
Mr. Maximoff leaves Alexandria on Friday next by the S.S. "Tsar" for Constantinople.
His successor,-Mr. Smyrnoff, is expected to arrive here about the begining of May.

The portrait of Lady (Eldon) Gorst has been painted by Professor von Herkomer and will be exhibited at this year's Royal Academy. The wife of the late Financial Adviser to the Egyptian Government is represented in an evening costume of some scarlet fabric.

Among the departures for Europe Turday by the S.E. "Schleswig" were Lady Elwin Palmer, Lady Bisset, General Fred Lance, C.B., Major and Mrs. L'Estrange Johnstone, Hon. Mrs. Ivor Guest, Mr. Freiherr and Baronin von Adelaheim, Hon. Mr. W. Colthorpe, Baron von Lodoreit, etc.
We hear that Mr. C. H. Walker, of the Ministry of Public Instruction, will shortly be appointed inspector under the Sudan Administration.

div.head: TRIBUNAL DE COMMERCE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: Livraibon de Titres Nouveaux R. Rutimeyer coatre la Sooiete Generate de Bressage et de Depots rqat-on on absoaoe d'un texto formal de loi appliquer par analogic an cas de vol on de perto de titres an portenr lea rfegles ddicts par.le oode en vue de la perto d'uue lettro do change

C'cst oe que pretend le demandeur qui s'a- dresse A la justice pour reclamer la dAlivrence d'un scoond titreou d'un duplicata. Lo tribunal mixtede commerce d'Alexandria vient de ddbouter M. Rutimeyer de sa de- mando et de lo condamner aux fraia Voici dans lean grandes liguea lee motifs invoqutfs par le juge.

Sans avoir A relever les differences qui pen- vent exister entro le caraotire d'ono luttre do change et celui d'une action au portenr, il oat de principo quo lbs societbs par actions dont les titres sout an porteur he doivent, commo oo titro l'indiquo, qu'un titre. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: En sympithie aveo Lindros, lo marche a on- vert on hausse et les prix ont iti pouases, maia oe beau mouvomont n'a pas tarde A suooombor sous le poids doi realisations. On oldture A dcs cours sensiblemont les mCmes qu'hier. Cepcndant, on remarqae de la hansso sur TAgricole A 13 3/8, sur la Dalra A 27 3/8 et sur l'Anglo-American Nile A-5 7/8. Par contro. il a baissede la New Bgyptian ASS et de la Brasierie dee Pynunides A 128 1/2.

On achte la Nationale A 27 7/16, Invest- ment A 2 7/32, la Land Bank A 9 7/8, les Eaux du Cairo A 1,975 et les Tramways d'Alexandria A 147, tandis qu'on vend la Banqub d'A- thonoi A 117, les Banx d'Alexandria A 16 7/16 et la Delta Light A 14 3/16. Lo nombre des transactions a 616 conside- rable.

div.head:
EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
CAIRO.
div.p: Open all the year round.
Electric Light. - LIFT - Moderate Charge

div.head: WINDSOR PHARMACY
div.p: Kaur-El-Nil Square, CAIRO. Best Chemical Products. English and foreign prescriptions carefully prepared by certificated chemists. Always in stock large assortment of English proprietary articles & specialties

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management. 11.11.906

div.head: PRIVATE THEATRICALS AT BULKELEY.
div.p: Yesterday evening, Mrs. Lang Anderson gave a most charming entertainment in Alderson's Garden to her numerous friends, who numbered between three or four hundred. The pro- gramme consisted of two farces, with an inter- lude in the shape of a violin solo, Mariani's "Abandono" exquisitely rendered by Miss Euna Anderson, whose skill kept the whole audience in an enraptured silence, which at the close gave plane to tumultuous applause. The guests were invited for 9 o'clock, and shortly after that hoar the theatre presented a most brilliant aspect, the ladies most richly gowned, their dresses blending with the large number of military uniforms. It is quite impos- sible to mention who were present. Suffice it to say that the gathering was representative of British society in Ramleh and Alexandria. The host and hostess, assisted by the Misses Anderson were indefatigable in attending to their guests, all of whom were unanimous in pronouncing the entertainment an immense success. The first play given was "Petticoat Perfidy," in which Mrs. Borton and Mrs. Gedge undertook the parts of the rival ladies, Mrs. Montresor and Mrs. Norwood Jones. They were simply perfect in their acting. As for Miss Lang Anderson, in the role of Juliette, the French soubrette, she fairly brought down the house by her espiegle rendering of the part. Her impersonation of the false Russian Princess was excellent and was acknowledged to be fully up to professional achievement. The second face, "A Regular Fix," was quite as amusing as "Petticoat Perfidy" and kept the aydience in roars of laughter. The principal part fell to Mr. J. R. Bassett, who filled the rele of Mr. Hugh de Bras te perfection. The part was somewhat trying, and called for a good deal of histrionic ability. But Mr. Basset never faltered from start to finish, and his vivacity and the aplomb with which he met his difficulties kept the audience spellbound with amusement Mr. E.T. Pool was also excellent as the old solicitor, and his "make up" was per- fect. In fact the "make up's" were all ex- tremely good, and Miss V. Aldereon, as the old housekeeper, Mr. Douglas Allen, as the bailiff, and Miss E. Allen as Matilda Jane, looked (as well as acted) their parts to perfec- tion. Mrs. Gedge and Miss Lang Anderson kept up the high standard of acting they had displayed in the previous farce, and the scene in which the former went into hysterics was a very capable piecoeof acting. Mr. P. J. Byrne and Mr. G. M. Sharpe were equally good in their roles, and from the begining to the end not one of the actors or actresses showed the slightest sign of faltering, and there was never any need of a prompter. Both the pieces could not in fact have been better acted, and immense pains had evidently been taken to ensure per- fection. After the dramatic part of the enter- tainment, an adjournment was made to the buffet, and the pleasant evening was brought to a close with a dance.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limites- free discussion.

div.head: AN INSTITUTE FOR CAIRO.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—I was glad to seoethis matter brought forward so ably in your leading article, and so forcibly seconded by the writer of "Under the Mosquito Net." Perhaps I may be allowed to trespass on your kindness to tell of the results of two years' work for the inauguration of such an establishment in this city. The idea was forced upon me by overhearing a young man remark that there are but two amusement to be had here,—getting drunk and the frequenta- tion of the places at which, on the authority of Solomon, the dead are unseen guests. Here was the truth bluntly stated, and I was obliged to think the matter over.

As I generally act after having lain a-think- ing, it was not long before I was in communi- cation with England regarding funds for a Young Men's Association. For a time I thought the ship I had launoched was going on very well, but suddenly she struck on a rock and foundered. That rock was the question of nationalities. I maintained that the association should admit all Europeans, the people who had the money said it should only admit Englishmen, I refused to have anything to do with it on their lines, they refused the funds on mine, and things came to a stand still, where they are likely to remain until the end of the ages.

Yet I did not despair. There is in Cairo, not a hundred miles from the old Alhambra, a very fine hall, and I decided to try to persuade the person who presides over its destinies to do something to stem the tide of vice and intemperance, and draw young men from the saloons by providing healthy amusement for them elsewhere. The answer I got was as follows : "If these men are not going to be converted, and to attend our meetings and Bible classes, they are as well in the saloons as here." There was nothing further to be said; it was a case of "Ayt sint quod sunt, aut non sint,"

Thus a splendid concert hall, which might, under proper management, be the means of keeping many young man away from the bqttle and worse, is allowed to waste its sweetness on the desert sir, because, in the opinion of its diredtress, a concert, like all other amusements, is of the Devil.—I am, etc.,

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.
xxxxx-1x.7

div.head: CHAMBRE DE COMMERCE INTERNATIONALE. RAPPORT DU COMITE
div.p: Messieurs, Nos premifcrea paroles seront poor adresse un dernier adien A oenx da nos mem bras qo nt dooddds depuis notre dernire AsssmblA amort a frappd impiteysiblejnent dans no mgs ot nous avons perdu 7 de nos oollbgiie epnis an an. Nous prions lean famnu de toevoir aveo nos regrets personnels, les sent iants de condoldanoe de la Chambre tout entiere.

Messieurs, Nous aronSl'honneur de voua rendre compte des thkyaox quo notre Comitf a aooomplis de- puia notrq Aaasmblta G4nfcale d'A nil dernier. Bien quVbetto Ipoque nous fusions aortis da la premire eiriance, il reitait snoore bean- coup A fairo poor qua, notre Institution (tt dtiiuitivement assise et nous avons on A com- puter notre organisation sur bien des points. Nous avons £ait de trAs seasibles progrea et, si nous no pouvona pas cons'ddrer 6ire an bout do nos poines, s'il mate encore d'dnergiquea effort A fairs, au moins arons-nous la satis- faction de voir la favour irolssante aveo la- quello les particuliers et las administrations dcoutODt ou demon dent nos avis.

Toutd'abord, nous rappcllerona oe que nous lee Elutions qu'ils ddsirent voir A certainee difnculWa qui les concernent ou conoernent leur profession ne sontpas aplanies commo ila le vondraient, les abqs ns aont pas encore ri- p rim is, les riformas se font attendre. A eela il y a de multiples raisons, maia las principalee sont.
1. qub souveot ila gardent lours souffranoes plus ou moins caohfes et n'en saisissont pas la Chambre.
2. quo les niclamationa les mieux justifidaa n'abouUssent pas du jour atlendemain et par le seal fait quo le dfair de voir oesser las abas a manifest.

3. las riformas si nombrenses et si desirables A apportar en bien des points ne dependant pas seulement des efforts qui sont fiuts poor las amener, maia sont le pins sou vent trie longues A obtenir et pins longues enooro A etablir d6- finitivoment.

Pendant l'annee eooniee, la Comits a an la satisfaction do voir que les qusetiOns qu'il a estuaires et soigneusement débarrassées de tout ce qui n'Atait pas l'intdret gdndral, ont troovd anpris des administrations compdtentes l'ao- cuoil favorable on les j nates sola dons Mon dovit Attendre.

C'est ainsi quo sar la question du Concor- dat priventif oe sont lee dtudee, lee trsvanx et les vm ox que yotre Comite a prison- tea au Gouvemement, qui ont servi de bases aux decisions de lA Conference judiciaire ; que, sur la question des billets d'aller et j+ tour, l'Atbiinistration des Chemins de for en a promis loVdtablissement progressifet proohain; que le Corps consolaire sans abandonner au- cune do tee prerogatives a consenti A uns con- sultation. otficieuse de la Chambre sur les liatos des dlectoba pour les juges assssseurs. — Le Gouvernement prond on tris ririeuso conside- ration et exabine lo moyen de satisbire au voeu dmis par la Chambre rolativement A une legislation .gendmlo concqrnant l'nsage des Poids ot Meeuros, et nona esperona que life obeervatioiir que nous avons prison toes relati- vemont A l'oxddntion du ddcret du 7 Janvier sur le droit de sdjoaranr les qtufia d'Alexan- drie amdneront une amodiation dee mesnres edietees pour les rendre vdritablement confor- mes aux usages ot aux in tort ts da Commerce. Enfin, nous avons en le plaisir de roir des com- mercants en ddsaooord fairo appel A l'arbitroge de la Chambre ; o'est 1A l'henreux avinement que nous derons signaler et enoonrager do tout notre pouvoir.

Notre comite qui a tenu de nombrenses sdanoes n'a pas bornd ses travaox anx ques- tions ci-dessus ; il a en A examber et A fiurfl valoir anprta doa Chemins de fer une recla- mation dcs importateura de menblei et en outre, A dtudier diverses antres questions uotammont cello des droits d'aocise snr les ootons filds, le drawback dm taboos, Etc. En dehors do oee questions il en mt une qui con- tinue A nous prioocuper constamment et qui a touto notre attention, car elle a use im- portance capitate, o'eat l'extonaion mtoo de notre Chambre, extension qui, hooreoaement, crolt sans oesse.

Depuis Pan dernier nous avons aoanis 184 membree noaveaux, oe qui porto le total actuel A .prts de 500 et nous voua signale- rona que les seals membres da Comito ont amene, en jnb 1904, par leur propaganda 1 pcrsonnelle, quaranto adhesions noUvellis. Ioi J nous ouvrirons une parenthfcae pour .vous odresaer uno nonvelle exhortation A nous amener de noaveaux ooUAgnoe. Plus nous serous uombroux, plus nous nemos forts ; anssl nous insistons . tout Dartiontitosment sur lo devoir qu'a chaoun ao nous de ro- crutor parmi ses oorreepondanta et see emit de noaveaux membres de notre institution. Nous ne morions trop insister sur oe point ot nous esperona que notre appbl aereentondu. Notre Bulletin eet dAplos en pins en favour et les articles qui y paraiaaent soot si bte- reasanta pour le Commerce Gdofnd, que de grands Jotunaox d'eoonomie politique ne dedaignent pas de las rrorodnire. Nona faisons appel A tons lea Membres de la Chambre pour qu'ila veuillqut bien de temps A autre prendre une part effective A la ridaction do ces articles. La pnhlioation de notre Bulletin, toujour* en progria, ripand vos noms et vos firme^ non seulement dans le pays, maia dans le monde entier et de oela aussi vous ne ponvez manquer de retirer des a vantages directs on indireots. Nous evens aotuollemant 140 correspondents dont 129 Chambrea de Commerce qui nous envoient riguliiremout d'inWressants Bnlletina.
La Biblitheque de la Chambre reçoit en outre 39 journaux et revues venant de toutes les parties du Monde et écrits en toutes langues.
Tous ces documents constituent une mine précieuse de renseignements pour qui veut bien les consulter; nous appelons votre atten-
tion sur la richesse de notre Bibliothèque et vous engageons vivement à l'utiliser; vous serez surpris de ce que vous y trouverez.

L'an dernier nous exprimions le regret que des Associations professionnelles ne se fondent pas en Egypte et l'espoir de voir bientôt les intéressés aux mêmes questions se grouper pour défendre leurs intérêts communs.

Nous sommes heureux de voir qu'après les courtiers en valeurs, les entrepreneurs de travaux publics et les intéressés à la naviga- tion fluviale ont pu constituer des Unions dont certainement ils retireront le plus grand profit; d'autres groupements sont en projet et le Comité de la Chambre sera toujours heureux de prêter son concours, soit pour aider à leur formation, soit pour prendre en mains la défen- se des intérêts généraux des corporations qu'ils représentent.

En résumé, vous voyez, Messieurs, que, quoi qu'on ait pu dire ou penser, votre Comité n'est pas resté inactif et a pu faire œuvre utile pour ceux qui ont bien voulu le saisir de la défense de leurs intérêts. Mais nous vous rappellerons ce que nous vous avons déjà dit 'il ne suffit pas de créer l'outil, il faut s'en servir.
Ne craignez donc pas de faire appel à votre Comité, vous y trouverez toujours le dévoue- ment à vos intérêts et la volonté énergique de rendre service au Commerce et à l'Industrie du pays.
Membres élus
MM. M. Bretschneider, A. Bircher, Maurice Cattaul Bey, Dessalles D'Epinoix, A. Ferrero, C. Hasselbach, L. Heller, M. Padova, A. Ros- tovitz Bey, Selim Sednaoui Bey.
MM. Reid, De Serionne, Fumaroli, Harris-
son.
Le Comité a été porté de 20 à 24 membres.
ALLOCUTION DU PRESIDENT
Messieurs,

Malgré mon désir de vous retenir ici le moins longtemps possible, je veux ajouter quelques mots au rapport de votre Comité et vous entretenir encore un peu de certaines questions qui touchent aux intérêts généraux du Commerce de l'Egypte.

Depuis quelques années, le pays vit dans une ère de prospérité croissante qui a peu d'exemples dans l'histoire économique des peu- ples, et cette prospérité, si grande déjà, n'a fait que s'accentuér pendant l'année qui vient de s'écouler. C'est là un état de choses écla tant aux regards de tous, une constatation que chacun est heureux de faire et je ne crois pas utile d'émailler de chiffres cette courte allocu tion pour faire ressortir davantage et mieux toucher du doigt une situation incontestable et incontestée.

Mais au milieu du riant tableau de l'avance ment de l'agriculture, du développement fruc tueux du Commerce et de l'Industrie, de l'essor général des affaires, il y aurait bientôt quelques ombres, si l'on n'y prenait garde.

La situation si satisfaisante de l'Egypte im- pose à tous, Gouvernement et particuliers, des devoirs nouveaux et impérieux. Eu ce qui con- cerne l'Etat, je laisserai de côté tout ce qui ne le touche pas d'une façon directe et absolue; mais j'estime que, plus la prospérité d'un pays est grande, plus aussi doivent être grandes la clairvoyance et la prévoyance des hommes qui le gouvernent. Dans un pays comme celui-ci en particulier, l'Etat acquiert une responsa- bilité énorme en raison de la façon dont le pouvoir s'exerce. C'est au moment où le pays est dans un heureux moment que les regards doivent se tourner vers l'avenir avec plus d'acuité, c'est alors que la prévision des be- soins futura est la plus indispensable et doit être la plus consommée, car la roue de la Fortune est parfois arrêtée par un grain de sable et les moindres fautes dans l'Administra tion ou dans l'Economie politique peuvent être le point de départ d'un arrêt dans l'essor de la fortune publique, voire le signal de sa dé croissance.

Là où existent des Institutions parlemen- taires, on peut dire que le Gouvernement est dirigé par les intéressés eux mêmes qui sont ainsi, en quelque sorte, les agents de leur for- tune; içi l'initiative de l'Etat, partant sa res- ponsabilité, est entière; mais les commerçants n'en seraient pas moins coupables s'ils n'u- saient de tous les moyens pour éclairer le Gouvernement et lui faire parvenir des avis. autorisés. Pour cela il n'est qu'un moyen vrai ment pratique, ce sont les Unions profession- nelles groupées autour de la Chambre de Com- merce et formant avec elle un tout indis- Boluble.

Comme vous le dit le rapport de votre Comité, ces Unions ou Associations commen- cent à surgir; on commence à comprendre dans tous les milieux commerciaux l'intérêt qu'ont les personnes s'occupant dh même genre d'af. faires, à s'entendre pour discuter les intérêts généraux et communs de leur corporation. Cet intérêt devient chaque jour plus intense au fur et à mesure que le développement du commerce amène un plus grand nombre de personnes ou de firmes à exercer une même profession. En effet, une foule de problèmes qui res taient ou pouvaient rester dans l'ombre, il y a peu de temps encore, réclament impérieuse ment une solution maintenant; l'essor même des affaires crée de nouvelles difficultés qu'il fauf vaincre et pour cela s'unir, sous peine de Voir les efforts rester stériles. Au précepte de Machiavel: "diviser pour régner," opposez la magnifique devise: Union fait la Force." Je sais bien que nombre de commerçants on d'industriels craignent les ententes, et je les comprend un peu, lorsqu'il s'agit de Trust, de Cartell, de Comptoir ou de Syndicat destinés à réglémenter des productions, des prix d'achat ou de vente, etc., et je trouve bien naturel le sentiment qui porte chacun à vouloir garder son indépendance absolue dans sa manière I de traiter les affaires; mais les associa
仁

tions dont je vous parle en ce moment ne doivent avoir pour but que la solution des problèmes généraux dans l'intérêt de tous, et ne pas toucher à la liberté indivi duale dans l'exercice de la profession, n'y le a donc pas de raisons, pour que ces associations ne se multiplient pas rapidement, tout milite, au contraire, en faveur de leur formation; que, dans chaque branche industrielle ou commer- ciale, un homme d'initiative et de décision se mette à la tête du mouvement et nous verrons bientôt, comme en Europe, chaque profession améliorer ses conditions d'exploitation et en cas de besoin se défendre energiquement et avec succes une foule d'ennuis, d'abus, d'en- traves dont tous se plaignent en les subissant, et que chacun en particulier est impuissant à réprimer, disparaitront devant la pression générale et la volonté universelle de les faire
cesser.
C

J'ajouterai encore sur ce sujet qu'il ne faut en aucun cas, vouloir transformer ces associa- tions en instruments de combat ou en machi- nes de guerre contre qui que ce soit; elles. doivent avoir pour but d'éclairer le gouverne- ment, les administrations, et même tout le public sur les besoins des professions qu'elles représentent ou sur les abus dont elles souf frent; montrer les améliorations & apporter, indiquer les moyens de ramener la prospérité disparue ou ceux à employer pour empêcher les affaires de péricliter. Elles doivent aussi faire acte de cette sage prévoyance dont je vous parlais tout à l'heure et en éclairant de conseils judicieux les hommes d'Etat chargés de la difficile mission de gouverner, être autant que possible les propres instruments de leurs destinées. Le rôle de ces associations doit donc ètre tout pacifique et diplomatique ; cela n'exclut l'énergie ni dans les décisions, ni dans les moyens à employer pour aboutir; mais je le répète, le but doit être d'édifier paisiblement et non de briser avec fracas. Ainsi elles prépa- reront pendant la prospérité les armes qui leur seront nécessaires pour combattre au jour où viendrait l'adversité.

La prévoyance de l'avenir est pour les parti- culiers comme pour les Gouvernements upe des qualités des plus éminentes et nous devons toujours avoir à l'esprit ce qu'en dit si juste- ment Charron dans son livre de la Sagesse "La prévoyance est un grand remède contre tous maux, lesquels ne peuvent apporter grande altération ni changement étant arrivés à un homme qui s'y attendait, comme au contraire ils blessent et endommagent fort ceux qui se laissent surprendre."

Comme je vous l'ai dit tout à l'heure, vous trouverez toujours dans la Chambre de Com- merce Internationale, l'Alma Mater qui sera prête à vous protéger et à diriger vos efforts elle prendra sous son égide toutes ces Unions, elle leur viendra en aide, elle fera siennes les justes revendications qui lui seront présentées et qui revêtiront alors la forme d'un vo général. On se demanders peut-être pourquoi il est nécessaire que les Associations profes- sionelles se groupent autour de la Chambre et pour quelles raisons il faut que ce soit elle qui doive être chargée en dernier ressort de présenter aux diverses administrations compé- tentes les désidérata exprimés par ces Unions. Il y a à cela deux raisons principales:

La première c'est que, malgré tout le soin avec lequel les délégués des Associations étu- dieront les questions, leurs conclusions seront toujours empreintes de l'esprit particulariste que revêtent les désirs exprimés par les inté- ressés, malgré leur bonne foi et la volonté d'y échapper. De plus il est extrêmement rare que les questions commerciales ou industrielles si particulières qu'elles paraissent ne touchent pas, par certains côtés, à d'autres professions que celle qui est la principale intéressée et qu'il peut être nécessaire aussi de les consulter pour que les intérêts de, tous soient sauve- gardés. Par conséquent il est nécessaire que le Comité de la Chambre, rassemblant tous les avis, toutes les opinions, envisageant et étudiant les questions sous leur aspect d'en- semble plus général et les dépouillant de ce que l'on appelle les questions de clocher, présente alors des réclamations ou des vœux qui sont positivement la résultante de l'intérêt universel. Il est facile de comprendre qu'il faut éviter à tout prix ces tiraillements bizarres d'associations demandant énergiquement des choses contre lesquelles d'autres associations protestent avec non moins de vigueur. En second lieu la Chambre, émanation de tous les commerces, de toutes les industries, de toutes. les nationalités représente la fédération des intérêts du pays tout entier et son autorité sera toujours supérieure à celle des Associa tions qu'on pourrait encore accuser quelque fois de ne représenter qu'une fraction insigni- fiante du Commerce général.

J'espère que ce ne sera pas en vain que j'aurai fait appel à vos sentiments de défense et de prévoyance solidaires et que l'an prochain. à pareil époque, la Chambre verra à côté d'Elle, pour le plus grand bien de tous, beaucoup de nouvelles Associations ou Unions profession- nelles, en même temps qu'elle constatera que le nombre de ses membres se sera accru con- sidérablement.

J'ai terminé, Messieurs, et je vous prie de me pardonner d'avoir retenu votre attention aussi longtemps; mon excuse est dans l'immense désir que j'ai de voir l'Industrie et le Com- merce du pays continuer leur marche ascendante et fructueuse et si mes paroles peuvent y con- tribuer pour une si petite part que ce soit, je me tiendrai fort heureux.

Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur de faire savoir au Public qu'à partir du 15 Avril courant, l'horaire des bureaux télégraphiques d'Abou-El-Shekook, Abou-Kébir, Belcas, Shibin El Kanater, Sheblanga, Dessouk, Faccoos, Kafr Sakr, Menouf, oi Minet El-Gamh, Mit-Ghamr, Mit-Yazid, Samanood, Tala, Talkha, Zifta Ville, Simballa wein, Ras-El-Khalig et Santa Gharbieh, sera modifié comme suit:
de 8 h. a.m. à 1 h.
et de 3 h. p.m. à 8 h.
p.m.

Le Caire, le 10 Avril 1905.

div.head: SOCIETE FONCIERE D'EGYPTE
div.p: AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES
Dans sa séance du 10 Avril 1905, l'Assem blée Générale Ordinaire a décidé la distribution de Une Livre Sterling (P.T. 97 20/40) par action à titre de dividende pour l'Exercice 1904.
Le paiement sera effectué à partir du .17 Avril 1905 et contre remise du coupon No. 6. au Caire et
à Alexandrie à la National Bank of Egypt.
L'Administrateur-Délégué Joseph A. Cattaui Bey

div.head: The Daira Sanich Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the Seventh Ordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at the National Bank of Egypt, Sharia Kasr-El-Nil, Cairo, Egypt, on Saturday the 29th April at 12 a.m. for the purpose of considering the Statement of Accounts and Balance Sheet to 31st Decem- ber 1904, the Auditors' Report thereon, and the Report of the Directors, for the Declaration of a Dividend, and the transaction of the ordinary business of the Company.
The Transfer Books of the Company will be closed from the 16th to the 29th April 1905, both inclusive.
SHARIA KASR-EL-NIL,
CAIRO,
By order of the Board, S. DE BILINSKI, Secretary.
8th April 1905. ·

Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer who wish to attend the General, Meet- ing of the Company must first deposit their Beurer Warrants together with a statement of their names and addresses :-
In London, with The National Bank of
Egypt, 4 and 5 King William
Street, E.C., ten clear days before the date of the Gene- ral Meeting (viz., not later than the 18th of April)
In Egypt, two clear days before the
date of the General Meeting (viz., not later than the 27th of April :-
At the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo.
National Bank of Egypt, Alexandria.
At the Anglo-Egyptian Bank,
Imperial Ottoman Bank,.
Credit Lyonnais,
Bank of Egypt.
Cairo
or
Alexandria.
The share warrants remaining so deposited"
until after the general meeting shall have been held.

Each depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, and a Ticket of Admission (which Ticket of must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and a Form of Proxy.

If the Depositor does not intend personally to attend the Meeting,a Proxy in favour of the person producing the Certificate must be lodged with the Company at its Cairo Office not less than 48 hours before the Meeting. 25706-4*-1

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
div.p: AVIS

La Société des Eaux du Caire porte à connaissance du Public, que son installa- tion pour la distribution des Eaux & Koub- beh-Zeitoun et Matarieh étant achevée, elle est prête à fournir dans les dites localités, l'eau pour la consommation, arrosage des jardins, chantiers de constructions et tous autres besoins.
Toute demande de concession devra être faite par lettre à l'adresse du Directeur de la Société des Eaux du Caire.
Le tarif du prix de l'eau dans les dites localités, tant par abonnement fixe que par compteur, est à la disposition du public, dans les-Bureaux de la Société Avenue de Boulac au
Caire.

La Société est prête à établir ses canalisa- tions d'eau dans les rues non pourvues de conduites, lorsqu'elle aura reçu des demandes suffisantes de concession pour une même rue.- Les habitants de Koübbeh, Zeitoun et Matarich sont dono priés de présenter leur demandes par groupes résidant dans une même rue, afin de permettre à la Société d'examiner sans re- tard leurs demandes, en vue de canaliser et de leur accorder des concessions d'eau. Le Caire, le 28 Janvier 1905.
Le Directeur, ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
